comments.text:
+Megan Brown
Of course lab-created chemicals are going to be purer than ones in plants, 
lab created chemicals adhere to a standard process, and cannot be affected 
by mutations within the plant itself or the other chemicals in the plant. 
SO if certain chemicals contained within the plant itself fight cancer, 
then we would find a way to replicate them, rather than exposing people to 
the other dangerous or untested chemicals inside of it.

Chemicals like nicotine, caffiene and THC are synthesized by plants to 
achieve a positive effect, usually it's a natural pesticide. But there are 
other chemicals within a plant that may also have been created, which might 
have undocumented or dangerous side effects, especially if administered in 
a new or novel way to the medical community. Take, for example, tobacco - 
while certain chemicals in the tobacco plant itself might not be dangerous 
alone, when burnt and inhaled they may become more damaging than they were 
when simply eaten. Nicotine isn't the only chemical in the tobacco plant, 
and, while the main addictive drug in cigarettes, it isn't the most 
dangerous chemical in them - that's why you can have e-cigs, which give 
people (lab-processed) nicotine to help control addiction, or even just as 
a regular stimulant.

Most people pushing for this kind of thing only really want to take 
marijuana to get high, which is bad enough with the drugs they use in 
hospitals already. If scientists can find away to isolate this mysterious, 
(and likely fictional) cancer-curing miracle drug in marijuana, they won't 
just hand you a joint and hope for the best, because there could be other 
unknown drugs within marijuana that are actively carcinogens, especially 
when burnt. They would take the chemical, and in the lack of an effective 
way to manufacture it in a laboratory, they would carefully cultivate the 
plant, extract the specific chemical from it, and then destroy the rest.

And that's assuming that there *is* a cancer-curing drug within marijuana, 
which is about as likely as people finding out cigarettes increase your 
longevity.
comments.author: Mirror Image

comments.author: venera13studios

comments.text:
+Connor Derting And literally right after that, in the exact same article, 
they say: "As of 2014, there are reports online suggesting that marijuana 
oil or “hemp” oil can cure cancer, as well as diabetes, ulcers, arthritis, 
migraines, insomnia, infections, and many other diseases. These claims are 
largely unsupportable. Relying on marijuana alone as treatment while 
avoiding or delaying conventional medical care for cancer may have serious 
health consequences."

I'm fine with you mining an article for quotes, but it's clear that they 
don't endorse relying on Marijuana without consulting a trained medical 
proffesional. And, like I said earlier, *not all cannabinoids are helpful, 
and not all of them are harmful*. Just like tobbaco, marijuana (the plant) 
has an assortment of chemicals, some of which can get you high when acting 
in tandem. Some *might* reduce the side effects or even completely 
eliminate certain types of cancer, but if they did, then it's prudent to 
replicate them in a lab, test them, and then distribute synthetic versions 
out to the public because while some specific compounds might fight cancer, 
within the marijuana itself lies other, more harmful, adulterants, which 
themselves might be carcinogens. Add to that, the traditional method of 
ingesting Marijuana is assuredly harmful and innefficient, in a case where 
precise dosage is key.

Everybody's cancer is different. Cannabinoids might help some certain types 
of cancer for certain people, but in other people the exact same compounds 
might make it worse. *If you need cancer treatment, consult a medical 
proffesional.* If a cannabinoid actually fights cancer, there's a chance 
they might already use it.

comments.text:
+Lucie Cat  You said: 'Want to mention that cancer survival rates in 
America with current treatment methods only have gone up 3% every since the 
"war on cancer" began about 40 years ago approx.'

You are wrong.  The following are the statistics for various types of 
cancer from the U.S government

The first percentage in each case is the 5-year survival rate in 1975; the 
second number is the survival rate from 2006, which is the latest year that 
they had available.

The improvement for all cancers except for endometrial cancer have 
improved, and for many of them, the survival rates have gone up 
dramatically, far in excess of your 3% claim.

Bladder Cancer 5-Year Relative Survival     71.5%     80.6%
Breast Cancer 5-Year Relative Survival     75.2%     90.6%
Colo-rectal Cancer 5-Year Relative Survival     48.6%     65.9%
Endometrial Cancer 5-Year Relative Survival     87.8%     84.7%
Kidney Cancer 5-Year Relative Survival     52.1%     73.5%
Leukemia 5-Year Relative Survival     33.1%     60.8%
Lung Cancer 5-Year Relative Survival     11.4%      17.5%
Melanoma 5-Year Relative Survival     81.8%     92.8%
Non-hodgkin's Lymphoma 5-Year Relative Survival     45.8%     70.3%
Pancreatic Cancer 5-Year Relative Survival     3.0%     7.3%
Prostate Cancer 5-Year Relative Survival     66.0%      99.6%
Thyroid Cancer 5-Year Relative Survival     92.3%     98.2%

top_comment.text:
Something I don't understand about bodily damage from the sun... If white 
is known to reflect sunlight and black will absorb it, why is it that light 
colored skin is more easily damaged by the sun even though it reflects the 
sun light while dark skin is not easily damaged by the sun yet it absorbs 
the sun light?﻿
top_comment.author: HeavenlyDismay

comments.text:
Like Molly said, darker skin = more melanin. Even though dark skin 
technically reflects less light, the melanin absorbs the harmful UV light 
before it can reach your DNA. I.e., it's the melanin doing the extra 
absorbing, not your cells.
comments.author: RoboBoddicker

comments.text:
The type of light that damages the cells of the body is UV radiation, light 
with a greater frequency and smaller wavelength than visible light. The 
light that you are referring to that is either reflected or absorbed is in 
the visible spectrum. Dark colored skin has more pigment or melanin that 
acts as a photo-protective factor, shielding the body from the DNA damage 
the sun can cause.
comments.author: Molly InKorea

comments.author: IceColdSniping

comments.text:
+IceCold-Gaming Vids and Sniping
If you look up the article "Evolution in action: a 50,000-generation salute 
to Charles Darwin", it'll help you understand what I'm about to tell you.

In the longest study of observed evolutionary change to date, a population 
of E. coli bacteria was put through extensive testing. The bacteria would 
be put through a trial during which about 99% would perish. The remaining 
1% would be allowed to reproduce until the original population was restored 
(which takes one day). Then the process was repeated.

After about 35 years and 50,000 generations, the final offspring were still 
E. coli bacteria. No macro-evolution had taken place. The only thing that 
the experiment could boast was the formation of a pseudo-beneficial 
mutation that allowed the bacteria to live on citrate instead of glucose, 
but damaged their ability to live on glucose! The scientists who headed the 
experiment admitted that it is really just a neutral mutation, but it was 
the closest thing that they got to a beneficial one.

The first hominids (apes with human-like features) supposedly appeared 5 
million years ago and evolved into humans since that time. The experiment 
above would tell us to expect no significant evolutionary change after 
50,000 generations. Considering that the early hominid's expected 
generation length was 20 years, 50K generations is a time scale of one 
million years or 20% of the allotted time for early hominids to evolve into 
humans.

In other words, the observed rate of evolution (or in this case, the lack 
thereof) is significantly slower that what is required to fit the 
theoretical timeline created by evolutionary scientists.

Of course, it could be argued that as this was a study on bacteria and not 
hominids, the numbers might have no correlation to the evolutionary rate of 
hominids or humans. There are two main issues with this argument.

1)The first is that the whole reason bacteria were used is because they are 
supposed to evolve faster, not just in a real time scale, but in a 
generational timescale as well. Bacteria such as E. coli get more mutations 
per generation than mammals do and should evolve faster even on a 
per-generation timescale.

2)The whole purpose of this experiment was to accelerate the evolutionary 
process so that we could see (as the title of the article put it) 
“evolution in action”.

So, to anyone who says that this rate of evolution is incongruent to that 
of early hominids and humans, I say that I wholeheartedly agree. The 
“evolution” shown in this experiment is significantly faster than what we 
would expect in humans and our supposed ancestors, even on a per-generation 
basis. I was actually being generous when I used the rate of evolution in 
this experiment as the rate of evolution for early hominids!
comments.author: Reuben Oakley

comments.text:
+Aegis of the dragon There is evidence that God is real. It starts with the 
massive count of eye-witnesses who have experienced the spiritual world in 
one way or another. After that you have scientific law.

Energy/matter cannot be created or destroyed (first law of thermodynamics). 
Ergo, the universe (or simultaneous presence of time, space and 
matter/energy) has also been around forever (though not necessarily in its 
current form).

However, the SECOND law of thermodynamics says that over time, mater/energy 
will decay into a less usable form. Put these together and the universe 
should be worn out by now (or at any point really, as you can go on forever 
in either direction of time).

The only way to get around this is for the universe to be an "open system" 
(where new energy is added in) but this creates a new problem. For the 
universe to be an open system there would need to be a source of infinite 
energy somewhere, otherwise this outside source would've run out by now as 
well.

Unfortunately, left to itself, an source of infinite energy would cause the 
universe to be in an energized state too chaotic for solid matter to exist, 
let alone life. In order to get around this you need the energy to be 
guided. It's like cleaning a room, you need to add energy, but it must be 
controlled otherwise you'll get a bigger mess than the one you started with.

Of course, like the energy source and the universe, the guide would have to 
have been around forever. This being (or beings) must exist for the 
universe to continue to be around. End result, God exists.

Now, that doesn't prove which god, but that's a different matter entirely. 
If you want more on that, check out the "Facts Behind the Faith" series on 
my channel. I've written enough here.
comments.author: Reuben Oakley

As true as this is, what we observe through our manipulations only proves

"For the last time EARTH IS NOT AN ISOLATED SYSTEM."
For the last time, IT DOESN'T MATTER. Like I said before, adding energy to 
the mix only makes the system reach entropy faster. The ONLY way around it 
is to have an intelligent life form purposely use time and energy to 
counteract the force of entropy. Adding energy without intelligent control 
will not help. This is not my claim, it was in my physics book!
"At the end I realized that speaking to you is useless cause you keep 
bringing up points that have been rejected a million times."
1) I have been using new points in every one of my replies.
2) You rejecting my points does not make them any less valid. When 
Aristotle started saying that the earth was round people thought he was 
crazy and most people, including scientists, rejected his claims. He was 
still right though.
"Also, getting 62 amino acids in the correct order in more than 1 billion 
year when the water is full of amino acids is not so rare."
1) Show me your math, what are the odds you calculated?
2) Most amino acids in the water today probably came from living creatures. 
There is only one know method of creating amino acids that could possibly 
happen naturally and it requires a lightning bolt of a specific energy 
range to hit a combination of gasses in water, preferably at night time. 
Even then though, the product is only 1% right-handed amino acids, which 
are covered in tar and carboxylic acid. If that sounds like conditions 
where life is likely to form to you then you are just hopeless.
3) Let's assume that you are right though, and amino acids were so 
plentiful that you could try to get this SMALLEST protein 1000 times every 
second in every square meter of ocean surface (it needs to be near the 
surface to be properly struck by lightning and that is where the gasses and 
acids are going to hang out anyways). So we got odds of 1 in 1.7x10^83, 
times 1000 attempts per second, times 360,000,000,000 square meters of 
ocean surface and you get 2.12x10^-69 or 1 in 4.72x10^68. See? It doesn't 
matter how much you try it, how much ocean space you say it can happen in 
or any of that, the odds are simply too low. It just won't happen.
"The mutations you are talking about on mice etc... are not always 
negative, if you read the published papers (a thing that you clearly don't 
do because you think it is all speculation) you will see what type of 
mutation they do and, above all, that is exactly what they did to know what 
proteins are described in which chromosome"
Actually, I got this information from reading different papers published on 
the subject. I find this kind of thing very interesting and researched it 
avidly for about a year. That was how I learned of the examples that I gave 
you (except the four-winged fly one, which was in a biology textbook). If 
you know of a beneficial mutation observed in a lab, please tell me about 
it. Because thus far, all you just said boils down to "There are good 
mutations, the scientists who do these tests know what the observed 
mutations do and this is how they learn about proteins and chromosomes." 
You never actually mentioned a beneficial mutation.
"Ans don't answer with the "common designer" thing because one of our 
steroid producing genes is a modification of 2 separate genes in older 
jawless fish which is exactly predicted by evolution."
Did you know that modern rockets used by NASA use an engine system that was 
modified from the designs of two older rocket engine systems? This does not 
mean that the new rocket evolved from the old ones, it means that the 
designers took two designs and put them together to make something better. 
If people can do that then why couldn't a god?
"the "design" of the human eye which has the same structure as all the 
animals in that evolutionary line (until fish) but different from all the 
other animals in the other evolutionary lines (as predicted and as shown by 
the phylogeny tree which is automatically built by an objective algorithm)."
Actually, squid and octopus have an eye extremely similar to those of 
humans, even though evolutionists say that humans did not evolve from 
either squid or octopi. This and other cases of "convergent evolution" are 
a big problem for evolutionists to get over because they cannot use the 
"common descent" argument to explain common design. None of these cases can 
be understood through the "evolutionary tree" and sometimes present a 
complete enigma to evolutionists. Creatures like the platypus, Tasmanian

have no idea how they evolved or what they even evolved from. Please tell

equipped with wings and echolocation, that the process wasn’t able to be 
captured, even in part, in the fossil record. The amount of time estimated

million years or less, that simply isn’t enough time for all of those 
changes to have happened. And after that, why have bats changed so little. 
Why would they go through massive changes so rapidly and then just stop and 
not do anything for 50 million years?

It's not just the uncontrolled cell division that is lethal, it is the fact 
that all of those rapidly dividing cells aren't performing any functions 
other than reproducing. Example, with lung cancer the cells that normally 
contribute to the functioning of the lung stop working, and only focus on 
growing and dividing. They get so out of control that they steal resources 
(glucose) from the cells that are functioning and cause them to die off, 
then they are replaced with non-functioning cells. So basically cancer 
makes your organs stop working, in the same way that a business would die 
if all it's employees never came to work and just sat at home eating.

comments.text:
+Hexus Serpent Some things I would like to hopefully clear up for you: 

1. Vaccines don't use mercury anymore, it was phased out in 2001. Even when 
it was used, thiomersal (An organic mercury-containing compound) was put 
into the vaccines as a preservative in controlled environments to keep 
vaccines fresh and usable over long periods of time (I think the influenza 
vaccine still uses it thiomersal today). Even then it isn't pure mercury, 
it uses 25 micrograms (0.000025), there is no way that that will ever harm 
you in any significant way. The only side effect from actually using this 
much is a slight redness at the injection site.

2. Vaccines do not cause autism, there was a study in 1998 that published a 
very shady relation between them. But it turned out it was fake, the doctor 
was using unethical and invasive methods on the children "volunteers," to 
which he was promptly banned from practicing medicine (Not sure what 
happened to him though afterwards). Autism also has no serious and fatal 
affects such as the diseases that can be cured with vaccines, sure you 
might be socially awkward, but it's better than suffering from a fatal 
disease that could actually kill you. Even then, most cases of autism 
nowadays aren't even on the extreme level where the person cannot function 
by themselves. There are more and more types of autism being classified as 
we progress and get better at detecting it. Vaccines do not rewrite your 
genetic coding to make abnormalities and give you autism.

3. The immune system cannot do this alone. The immune system is made up of 
two parts, innate and adaptive, you need both to live. The adaptive only 
works on diseases you've already experienced. Without a vaccine or any 
outside help, it would take you roughly two weeks to fully be able to 
combat a new disease you have never experienced. But by that time, you 
would probably be suffering so much your immune system has already been 
destroyed so much it can't do anything (Or you'd be dead). Memory cells 
recall previous events of the disease (from your vaccine) and can almost 
destroy the disease before you even sneeze. Vaccines manipulate your to 
create a natural body response that it can use over and over again. 
Vaccines use attenuated nonvirulent forms of the disease so it doesn't 
seriously hurt you or accidentally give you the disease it's trying to 
prevent.

4. There is no government conspiracy surrounding the cure for cancer.

5. People who do not receive vaccines can cause previously deadly viruses 
and diseases to mutate. Because someone hasn't already been injected with 
the vaccine or experienced that disease yet, it gives the disease a toehold 
in humanity so it can overcome the current vaccines. It can take a disease 
less than five years to fully mutate into something that could cause an 
epidemic. If you were being treated for a disease but didn't take all or 
any of your meds, selective pressure would take over and cause harm to you. 
Selective pressure happens when you don't get enough of what you need to 
fully combat your sickness and the disease can come back right again more 
powerful. So if you were to only take a weeks worth of antibiotics but need 
three and you were feeling better already, it could come back and 
potentially kill you or make you seriously sick based on what the virus is. 
The same goes for vaccines, if you didn't get enough or any vaccines, the 
disease can come back fully functionally to cause an epidemic based on what 
it is.

6. Eating healthy is not enough to save you from cancer, nor is it enough 
to stop diseases and bacteria from killing you. Eating a banana will not 
save you from cancer if you don't have it or if you already have it. And 
being vaccinated against certain infectious diseases could, in fact, 
prevent cancer in many ways.

Much of the evidence and stories you have presented with the people you 
have responded with of surviving/dying of cancer/diseases with/without 
treatment can either be attributed to luck, or you are fabricating them. 
Nearly all of the tales you have claimed to be real seem very fairy 
tail-like and cliche in the sense it is the same story many people use over 
and over again to say that their methods work. It is true that chemotherapy 
may not work sometimes, but it does also work a lot of the time. Your 
ignorance is almost borderline arrogance at this point with all the replies 
you have gotten from your original comment, while they have been providing 
evidence, you've been pulling stories out of your ass. And being mean to 
people such as telling them to "get cancer, take chemo, and then DIE" is 
not the approach you want to be taking when you wish to "educate" people on 
the subject at hands. You are extremely biased towards your own opinion and 
references to the point where you think the other side of the treatment 
does nothing at all. Also your absence of sources and references is 
concerning seeing as you supposedly know so much about the topic. Your 
arguments are forfeit without actual facts opposed to you using 
fear-mongering and rabid insults. I suggest you do some actual proper 
research instead of spouting nonsense on the internet. The people who 
create vaccines and treat patients with chemo know a lot more than you do, 
so you should do some actual proper research on the topic at hand before 
going around saying something this irrational.

+Hexus Serpent I can tell you the reason why you didn't catch a disease 
when you lived in the wild: Diseases are species-specific. Meaning you 
can't catch a disease from an animal, only from other humans. Diseases 
spread from human to human so if you live in isolation of course nobody can 
contract a disease. Also I'm quite sure you were enjoying many of the 
comforts of civilization anyway, knives, tools, clothing etc and also 
humans don't have many animals we have to fear, bears and wolves being some 
of the few exceptions. But that's nothing like what the vast majority of 
animals are going through, being in fear of being eaten 24/7. If life in

proof that autism is not in any way linked to Thimerosal. I got all shots 
there are and I'm not autistic. Barely anyone is autistic anyway. How would 
you explain that? Vaccination rates have been dropping over the last decade 
due to the paranoia caused by aforementioned forged study, yet there is no 
drop in autism diagnoses in infants. Kids are still getting autism even 
though people stopped vaccinating them? How come? I tell you how. You had 
autism when you where born because it's caused by a genetic mutation, it's 
a "birth defect" for the lack of a better word. No offense, I'm not saying

lie and a lie that you really don't have to convince yourself of.

And concerning the formaldehyde thing, there is no such thing as "taking

difference between formaldehyde in a shot or in a fruit. I can look up

amounts of formaldehyde in a vaccine are so tiny compared to fruit we eat 
every day that it's really ridiculous to claim that it harms you. Those 
doses are ridiculously minute and not harmful to humans whatsoever.

the average person being in the center of the bell and extremely dull or 
bright people at the extremes.  Its fairly self-explanatory.  There are 
bell curves in all sorts of things - physical strength, speed, typing 
ability, time it takes people to eat breakfast, etc... 
Its true that dumb people tend to have more kids, but smart people breed

intelligence could go down if that continues, but the brightest aren't

not intelligence, nor can education increase intelligence to 
any significant degree.  Genetic brothers who grow up apart have closer 
intelligence than non-brothers who grow up together.  

There aren't two distinct groups - non successful and successful.  There is 
a bell curve spectrum with everybody somewhere along it.  In the entire 
gene pool there is a tug toward higher intelligence.  The tug is weak 
at the bottom, but very strong at the top.  Dumb people still want to mate 
with someone intelligent (successful), but they have little ability to do 
so, so the force is weak.  High IQ people have great ease finding another 
high IQ person.  They're all looking for each other.  The upper end of the 
bell curve, by its very nature, will always be a tiny portion of the 
population, but that doesn't stop them from stretching the extremes of 
human intelligence further and further.  Like I said, the whole gene pool 
stretches towards higher IQ, but the smartest stretch faster, so the human 
IQ range is being widened like the pulling of molasses out of a jar.  Look 
at Jews - tip of the spear in IQ.  Only a tiny part of the population, but 
extremely successful people as a group.

comments.text:
+Diego Barragán Actually, the OP is correct to suggest that the Health Care 
Industry makes a great profit off of cancer patients. The industry makes 
roughly $100billion annually (out of about $850 billion in profit/year) off 
of the disease and, despite the rigorous research being done to find a cure 
or 'golden treatment', the World Health Organization has predicted that the 
number of people who get cancer will almost DOUBLE by 2030, from a current 
13 million new cancer patients/year to 22 million new cancer patients/year. 
Despite numerous carcinogens being well-known by respective Medical 
Institutions and Governmental Departments, little to no work is being done 
to prohibit this (such as GMOs or Pesticides, what is covered over the food 
you eat). Companies already earn, on average, over $100k per patient per 
year. One reason why the price is so high is because new cancer drugs have 
no competitors, which means the price can be gauged to what the industry 
wants. Center's for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS) establishes prices 
for all drugs that are paid for under Medi(care/aid), health insurances set 
prices to coincide with this, BUT CMS does not establish fees for cancer 
drugs, allowing prices to skyrocket.

There's far too much to talk about regarding this issue, but just note that 
things such as cancer research, however it may be perceived by the general 
public, is not seen in the same way to those who make a buck off of it. It 
turns out that the best way to fend off cancer is to live a lifestyle with 
as little exposure to carcinogens as possible. Why do you think cancer 
rates were severely low in the early 1900s?

comments.text:
I don't know the answer, but would expect the resulting flow field to be 
radically different to that from supersonic travel in the air. Across a 
shockwave, the density of air increases in density, increasing in pressure 
and in temperature. It is for this reason that the classical 
"incompressible" (i.e. density is not changing) fluid dynamics can not be 
applied to flow approaching Mach 1.

Water is obviously a lot more dense than air (1,000kg/m3 compared to 
1.225kg/m3), and is also generally viewed as being incompressible, 
therefore the physics that dictate the flow will be different to that in 
air.

If I was going to make a guess about what would happen, I would say that 
the friction between the object and the water would literally boil the 
water, surrounding the body with water vapor (a gas). I believe this would 
be a form of cavitation. I wouldn't want to say how this gas (or the 
shockwaves within it) would interact with the surrounding water however.

comments.text:
Natural resonance--essentially, a naturally frequency.

There is a certain frequency where one's voice can shatter glass. Think of 
it like this:

Non-natural frequency is akin to trying to run into a brick wall with just 
your body. The wall would not move, or if it did move, it would move only 
slightly. Either way, it doesn't break the wall.

Now, natural frequency is like ramming a car into a brick wall. The brick 
wall would "shatter" all over the place and bricks would be sent flying.

comments.text:
+Kevin Baker Our canines are smaller than carnivores because we're 
omnivorous. Read this extract on the digestive system of Humans:

Human Digestive Tract

The human digestive tract bears NO resemblance to that of herbivores.

In fact, it should be very obvious how very similar the human and carnivore 
digestive systems are. Here’s counting the ways...

Dogs and humans have canine teeth.
Dogs and humans eat a meal, and then may not eat again for a few hours, or 
days. (Herbivores graze all day long, nearly every waking moment looking 
for forage.)
They use an up and down chewing motion of the jaws
Length, digestive enzymes and function of the stomach are nearly identical 
in human and carnivore digestive systems. No digestion occurs in the 
rabbit's stomach; in a cow, digestion does not occur until stomach number 4.
Small intestine, appendix (cecum) and colon have identical functions in 
human and carnivore digestive systems, though there are a couple physical 
differences. 

Humans don't have a cecum, per se. Instead, the beginning of the large 
intestine is called the 'cecum.' It is nothing more than a segment of the 
colon. The appendix which has no known use, is attached to the large 
intestine at the junction of small and large intestines. 

Dogs have no appendix, but at the spot where the small intestine joins the 
large intestine, dogs have a small, S-shaped appendage named the cecum 
which serves the dog about like the human appendix does humans - its use is 
minor or undetermined.
Neither carnivores or humans have digestive systems that break down or 
utilize the cellulose in plant cell walls. (Herbivores use an army of 
bacteria and an extended transit time to break down cellulose to a usable 
form.)
Human and carnivore digestive systems are designed for and equipped to eat 
meat. Both humans and carnivores eat and break down animal proteins, lipids 
and vitamins directly from animal sources. (Herbivores by definition do not 
eat animals, but they still need 'animal protein,' and they obtain it from 
the many pounds of bacteria which they continually digest.)
Human Digestive Tract Sketch
Human digestion does not break down plant materials efficiently.

Humans CAN extract and utilize the carbohydrates in plants (not cellulose), 
which is where humans and pure carnivores differ:

Dogs cannot break down carbohydrates at all. But human saliva contains 
amylase, which can digest carbohydrates (but not cellulose, which is too 
complex for amylase).

This is why humans are categorized as omnivores, while also having a 
carnivore digestive system.

What does this mean?

Humans should be eating a LOT MORE MEAT and animal fat, and a lot less 
carbohydrates, especially refined carbs and grains (including whole grains).

I know this flies in the face of quite a bit of current accepted dietary 
theory.

But, let's think this through for half a minute:

Current dietary recommendations have been around for 50+ years.  If these 
dietary guidelines were even half effective, Americans would be getting 
healthier. As it is, on the current low fat, high carb guidelines, every 
known chronic degenerative disease has reached epidemic proportions, and 
66.7% of Americans are not just overweight, but obese.

Something's wrong with THAT picture.

Low fat, high carb is NOT working! If what we’re doing isn’t working, don’t 
you think we should be trying something different already??

- See more at: 
http://www.raising-rabbits.com/carnivore-digestive-system.html#sthash.QSuJpIOJ.dpuf

comments.text:
+arrab11 "If we are omnivores then why its gross to just look at road kill, 
because real omnivores eat that, and no just a nice peace of meet without 
bones and organs but the whole thing and weel satisfied with what he or she 
ate."

I think you're thinking of scavengers which are mainly carnivorous. Such as 
a vulture or crows. Humans may have been at one point but we have since 
evolved to be hunter/gathers. Our stomachs are no longer designed to digest 
half rotten meat that are crawling with all sorts of diseases and 
parasites. Which is why a week old deer carcass isn't that appealing. Its a 
different story when the kill is fresh though. I know a few people who will 
take a deer they just hit to the butcher. Oh, and we do often use the bones 
and organs of animals. Casings of sausages are usually made out of 
intestines. Tongues of various animals are often consider a delicacy along 
with the brains and heart. Its also not uncommon for the liver of an animal 
to be cooked and eaten. Hell, even blood is often used. Bones can be boiled 
down into a broth along with the hooves or feet of the animal. We actually 
use just about every part of an animal we butcher. The bits we don't we 
grind into food for our pets.

"If meet is healthy then explain why china or other Asian countries that 
eat mainly diet high in carbohidrate foods have the lowest % of heart and 
cancer  illness."

Meat contains carbohydrates. Albeit not as much as fruits, veggies, or 
grains but they are also high in protein and fats which the body needs to 
operate effectively. You also make it out as if most Asians enjoy a 
primarily vegan diet which is just not the case. Most Asian dishes 
incorporate a meat of some kind. Its actually kind of rare to eat a meal 
that doesn't include meat in most places throughout Asia. They do also eat 
a lot of fresh vegetables with that meat though which is probably the 
primary reason why they have lower risk of heart disease and cancer 
compared to westerners who consume a more processed food heavy diet. Which 
just goes back to what I was saying earlier about a balanced diet being 
important.

comments.text:
There is something called telomer, the end part of DNA. Only in sex cells 
do these completely regenerate after the DNA replications. What happens as 
our time goes on, is that these 'ends' become shorter, and the body's 
production of DNA, which are fundamental blue prints for all the enzymes 
that facilitate almost every process in our body metabolism, become 
incapable of keeping up with the dying cells. Thus, when the person grows 
older, metabolism begins to drop (due to lack of catalysts to push the 
demanded work output) and the immune system also goes down.

Finally, when these cells begin to die faster than be produced, we die.

comments.text:
+Spark1383 I think what you're talking about is telomere shortening. You 
see, there are these regions of repetitive nucleotides that are attached to 
our chromosomes called telomeres. They are there to prevent chromosomes 
from joining together and they also prevent chromosomes from deteriorating 
(both of which can lead to mutations). But, each time a cell divides (in 
certain types of cells), these telomeres get shorter, and this shortening 
is one of the factors involved in aging. But, there are tons of other 
factors involved in aging as well. Not to mention that there are many 
theories out there that explain why we age and why we die.

wasn't trying to start a comment war, I apologize for both though. The 
definitions of those words aren't "painfully obvious" but if you have a 
decent understanding of English sentence structure then its not too 
difficult to figure out. Like the word "And" we use it all the time and 
after much use you should be able to sum up a definition through your 
pattern of usage. Its used mostly in two ways. Connecting two words in a 
sentence like "Peanut butter AND Jelly". The second use being an 
introduction to a new comment. Like " You have blue eyes AND brown hair." 
I'm not going to spend all day doing every word but we'll do another. 
BECAUSE. Because gives reason for a previous event or action. Like "I 
brought an umbrella BECAUSE it was raining outside." You can think of using 
it as the action was the cause of the event. All these words are 
conjunctions, which are used to connect separate events or clauses into one 
whole. Again sorry for the disruption. It was not intended.

comments.text:
I had the same definition for 'the'. 'If', I thought was to describe any 
other possibilities that a situation might have, depending on the sequence 
done, unless that was what you meant by 'conditional qualifier', and what I 
wrote was an example. For 'because', I had also had the same definition, 
one event that causes another, or a chain of events, for example: I rob a 
bank, and because I rob a bank, someone calls the Police and they track me 
down and arrest me. 'Of', I was having a hard time attempting to think of a 
definition. 'How', what I thought it meant, was to explain why or, well, 
how something happens.
comments.author: That Crazy Guy Productions

comments.text:
'If' is a conditional qualifier. 'Because' is used to connect 2 events, one 
that is responsible for the other. 'And' is used to group two or more 
like-items. 'Of' is used to indicate a subset of another thing. 'How' is 
used at the start of questions for asking about a process. 'What' is at the 
start of questions, but unlike 'how' it indicates you are asking for 
information about a cause or object. 'The' is a pronoun used to shorten 
referring to a specific object, event, etc.

That's the best I can think of, but you'd have to polish those definitions 
before putting them in a dictionary.

Natural selection is not responsible for human evolution.

This is by far the most misrepresented fact about Evolution.  Natural 
selection has been falsified by lab experiments as a possible mechanism by

top_comment.author: Global Warming Skeptic

comments.text:
+TheMimiker +Jack Harrison  Behe doesn't argue against Evolution.  Behe's 
arguments deal with natural selection and mutations.  He doesn't debate 
that some form of evolution happens, only the mechanism by which it 
happened.

I'm not worried  about what people believe.  What I'm worried about is the 
data, and that includes with Behe.

Had Behe have just said "I do not believe in natural selection," that 
statement would hold no weight.  But, Behe did provide lots of evidence for 
his assertions.

Same for any of his critics, but his critics have not provided any 
justification to say Behe is wrong without creating even more problems of 
their own.

*Have I tried looking for evidence?*

There isn't a shred of evidence that natural selection and random mutations 
combined are capable of producing the diversity of life we see today from a 
common ancestor. 

The entire premise cannot be falsified because any witnessed change can 
always be said to fit better with its environment, whatever it is.

comments.text:
+Mr JimFit It's my turn to show how terrible your arguments are and destroy 
them. I will now begin ;)

*"The only thing that we know it can precede Materialism is consciousness 
and God is a Cosmic Consciousness"*

Haha, your "evidence" for this stuff isn't even accepted in the scientific 
community. It has barely been peer reviewed and there is no evidence that 
photons can decide what they want to do. They don't have a consciousness, 
and just because we can't detect them in a wave and particle form at the 
same time, doesn't mean they're consciously changing from one to another.

*"The fine-tuning of the universe to support life is either due to law, 
chance or design
It is not due to law or chance"*

*"Therefore, the fine-tuning is due to design"*

Wow, really? That provided no evidence whatsoever that the Universe doesn't 
support life because of law or chance.

*"Life has certain minimal requirements;"*

*"long-term stable source of energy, a large number of different chemical 
elements, an element that can serve as a hub for joining together other 
elements into compounds, etc.
In order to meet these minimal requirements, the physical constants, (such 
as the gravitational constant), and the ratios between physical constants, 
need to be withing a narrow range of values in order to support the minimal 
requirements for life of any kind.
Slight changes to any of the physical constants, or to the rations between 
the constants, will result in a universe inhospitable to life."*

Although that might be true, that isn't proof that an imaginary sky daddy 
created us. hah!

*"The constants are selected by whoever creates the universe."*

Ok, but there's no evidence whatsoever that somebody (or in this case 
something) created the Universe.

*"Examples of finely-tuned constants"*

I'm not going to quote the entire examples you put there, but that still in 
know way proves a god exists. Why do you people think that just because 
something hasn't been figured out yet, that "it must be god." 

*"These six numbers constitute a ‘recipe’ for a universe. Moreover, the 
outcome is sensitive to their values: if any one of them were to be 
‘untuned’, there would be no stars and no life. Is this tuning just a brute 
fact, a coincidence?"*

*"Or is it the providence of a benign Creator?"*

That again doesn't prove a god! Just because things turned out right for 
the Universe, doesn't mean it was created! It's like saying, "This murder 
was carried out so perfectly, we don't even have a suspect. Oh, it must be 
that Jelly Bean." You just throw in god where science hasn't answered 
something.

Did you know that back then, people used to think seizures were caused by 
the devil trying to take over a person's body!? Then science came along and 
proved them wrong, showing it wasn't a supernatural being.

People also used to think the Earth was flat, science came along at proved 
those theists wrong.

People used to think the Earth was the center of the Universe... Science 
proved them wrong.

*"Atheistic responses to the fine-tuning argument"*

*"There are two common responses among atheists to this argument."*

*"The first is to speculate that there are actually an infinite number of 
other universes that are not fine-tuned, (i.e. – the gambler’s fallacy). 
All these other universes don’t support life. We just happen to be in the 
one universe is fine-tuned for life. The problem is that there is no way of 
directly observing these other universes and no independent evidence that 
they exist."*

Here's possible evidence that shows that there may be other universes.
http://www.fromquarkstoquasars.com/did-our-universe-collide-with-another-when-it-was-380000-years-old/

*"What we have is evidence for fine-tuning. You don’t dispute that. What 
you dispute is what the evidence means. There are only two possibilities: 
chance or not chance, if not chance then we are here by intention."*

Did you read that New Scientist article? Doesn't seem like it. Here's a 
quote from it. *Weinberg went on to clarify that invoking a benevolent 
designer **does not** count as a genuine explanation*

*"Big Bang cosmology now strongly indicates that time-space energy-matter 
had a sudden creation event approximately 14 billion years ago."*

That still isn't evidence for a creator. Most scientists say, "We know that 
it had a spontaneous creation, we just don't know how. We will one day with 
more research!" Just inserting god into something science doesn't know just 
holds back science. Well, that's all Religion is good for, right? Holding 
back humanity.

For your 1-15 argument, good job Copy Pasting all of that from a Christian 
Website. You know, a christian website that loves making connections that 
don't exist and loves taking things out of context to favor their beliefs. 
I don't even know if I want to disprove all that. Let me know if you want 
me to, I'll do it tomorrow after work.
comments.author: Unsolved Paradox

comments.author: CfTheBest HD

comments.text:
+Unsolved Paradox Hello Random cosmic accident that nothingness spewed 
without free will or purpose, lets destroy your philosophy, you said

*God isn't a theory. Barely even a hypothesis*

That we are here by chance is stupid and lucks scientific support, we are 
here due to intention or no intention, since the Universe began to exist 
(matter space time) then the cause of the Universe is by definition 
transcendent or supernatural if you like.
The only thing that we know it can precede Materialism is consciousness and 
God is a Cosmic Consciousness.

Four intersecting lines of experimental evidence from quantum mechanics 
that shows that consciousness precedes material reality (Wigner’s 
Quantum Symmetries, Wheeler’s Delayed Choice, Leggett’s Inequalities, 
Quantum Zeno effect):

@1

Was there intention behind our existence? Of course there was and now we 
can prove it, its called the Fine Tuning argument.

*The fine-tuning argument*

The argument goes like this:

The fine-tuning of the universe to support life is either due to law, 
chance or design
It is not due to law or chance

Therefore, the fine-tuning is due to design

What does it meaning to be fine-tuned for life?

Here are the facts on the fine-tuning:

Life has certain minimal requirements;

long-term stable source of energy, a large number of different chemical 
elements, an element that can serve as a hub for joining together other 
elements into compounds, etc.
In order to meet these minimal requirements, the physical constants, (such 
as the gravitational constant), and the ratios between physical constants, 
need to be withing a narrow range of values in order to support the minimal 
requirements for life of any kind.
Slight changes to any of the physical constants, or to the rations between 
the constants, will result in a universe inhospitable to life.

The range of possible ranges over 70 orders of magnitude.

The constants are selected by whoever creates the universe. They are not 
determined by physical laws. And the extreme probabilities involved 
required put the fine-tuning beyond the reach of chance.

Although each individual selection of constants and ratios is as unlikely 
as any other selection, the vast majority of these possibilities do not 
support the minimal requirements of life of any kind. (In the same way as 
any hand of 5 cards that is dealt is as likely as any other, but you are 
overwhelmingly likely NOT to get a royal flush. In our case, a royal flush 
is a life-permitting universe).

*Examples of finely-tuned constants*

Here are a couple of examples of the fine-tuning. Craig only gave one 
example in the debate and didn’t explain how changes to the constant would 
affect the minimal requirements for life. But Bradley does explain it, and 
he is a professional research scientist, so he is speaking about things he 
worked in his polymer research lab. (He was the director)

a) The strong force: (the force that binds nucleons (= protons and 
neutrons) together in nucleus, by means of meson exchange)
if the strong force constant were 2% stronger, there would be no stable 
hydrogen, no long-lived stars, no hydrogen containing compounds. This is 
because the single proton in hydrogen would want to stick to something else 
so badly that there would be no hydrogen left!
if the strong force constant were 5% weaker, there would be no stable 
stars, few (if any) elements besides hydrogen. This is because you would be 
able to build up the nuclei of the heavier elements, which contain more 
than 1 proton.
So, whether you adjust the strong force up or down, you lose stars than can 
serve as long-term sources of stable energy, or you lose chemical 
diversity, which is necessary to make beings that can perform the minimal 
requirements of living beings. (see below)

b) The conversion of beryllium to carbon, and carbon to oxygen
Life requires carbon in order to serve as the hub for complex molecules, 
but it also requires oxygen in order to create water.
Carbon is like the hub wheel in a tinker toy set: you can bind other 
elements together to more complicated molecules (e.g. – “carbon-based 
life), but the bonds are not so tight that they can’t be broken down again 
later to make something else.
The carbon resonance level is determined by two constants: the strong force 
and electromagnetic force.
If you mess with these forces even slightly, you either lose the carbon or 
the oxygen.
Either way, you’ve got no life of any conceivable kind.

*Is the fine-tuning real?*

Yes, it’s real and it is conceded by the top-rank of atheist physicists. 
Let me give you a citation from the best one of all, Martin Rees. Martin 
Rees is an atheist and a qualified astronomer. He wrote a book called “Just 
Six Numbers:

The Deep Forces That Shape The Universe”, (Basic Books: 2001). In it, he 
discusses 6 numbers that need to be fine-tuned in order to have a 
life-permitting universe.

Rees writes here:

These six numbers constitute a ‘recipe’ for a universe. Moreover, the 
outcome is sensitive to their values: if any one of them were to be 
‘untuned’, there would be no stars and no life. Is this tuning just a brute 
fact, a coincidence?

Or is it the providence of a benign Creator?

There are some atheists who deny the fine-tuning, but these atheists are in 
firm opposition to the progress of science. The more science has 
progressed, the more constants, ratios and quantities we have discovered 
that need to be fine-tuned. Science is going in a theistic direction. Next, 
let’s see how atheists try to account for the fine-tuning, on atheism.

*Atheistic responses to the fine-tuning argument*

There are two common responses among atheists to this argument.

The first is to speculate that there are actually an infinite number of 
other universes that are not fine-tuned, (i.e. – the gambler’s fallacy). 
All these other universes don’t support life. We just happen to be in the 
one universe is fine-tuned for life. The problem is that there is no way of 
directly observing these other universes and no independent evidence that 
they exist.

Here is an excerpt from an article in Discover magazine, (which is hostile 
to theism and Christianity).

http://discovermagazine.com/2008/dec/10-sciences-alternative-to-an-intelligent-creator

The second response by atheists is that the human observers that exist 
today, 14 billion years after the universe was created out of nothing, 
actually caused the fine-tuning. This solution would mean that although 
humans did not exist at the time the of the big bang, they are going to be 
able to reach back in time at some point in the future and manually 
fine-tune the universe.
Here is an excerpt from and article in the New Scientist, (which is hostile 
to theism and Christianity).

www.newscientist.com/article/mg20026852.500-why-its-not-as-simple-as-god-vs-the-multiverse.html

So, there are two choices for atheists. Either an infinite number of 
unobservable universes that are not fine-tuned, or humans go back in time 
at some future point and fine-tune the beginning of the universe, billions 
of years in the past.

That we are here by chance is meaningful. We are either here by intention 
or not, if not then by definition we are here by chance.
What we have is evidence for fine-tuning. You don’t dispute that. What you 
dispute is what the evidence means. There are only two possibilities: 
chance or not chance, if not chance then we are here by intention. You have 
to ask yourself which of the two, given the evidence we have, is more 
plausible. Intention is clearly more plausible due to analogous reasoning. 
There is no reason to believe that fine-tuning is the result of chance. The 
only reason why people believe that it’s just a coincidence is because they 
wish to believe it.

1. like causes like effects
2. the effect of fine-tuning is caused by intelligence
3. Therefore, I think there is not enough evidence to choose between chance 
or intelligence.

Theism Compared To Atheistic Materialism, which one should be rejected as a 
valid scientific hypothesis?

1. Naturalism/Materialism predicted time-space energy-matter always 
existed. Whereas Theism predicted time-space energy-matter were created. 
Big Bang cosmology now strongly indicates that time-space energy-matter had 
a sudden creation event approximately 14 billion years ago.

2. Naturalism/Materialism predicted that the universe is a self sustaining 
system that is not dependent on anything else for its continued existence. 
Theism predicted that God upholds this universe in its continued existence. 
Breakthroughs in quantum mechanics reveal that this universe is dependent 
on a ‘non-local’, beyond space and time, cause for its continued existence.

3. Naturalism/Materialism predicted that consciousness is a ‘emergent 
property’ of material reality and thus should have no particularly special 
position within material reality. Theism predicts consciousness precedes 
material reality and therefore, on that presupposition, consciousness 
should have a ‘special’ position within material reality. Quantum Mechanics 
reveals that consciousness has a special, even a central, position within 
material reality. -

4. Naturalism/Materialism predicted the rate at which time passed was 
constant everywhere in the universe. Theism predicted God is eternal and is 
outside of time. – Special Relativity has shown that time, as we understand 
it, is relative and comes to a complete stop at the speed of light. (Psalm 
90:4 – 2 Timothy 1:9) -

5. Naturalism/Materialism predicted the universe did not have life in mind 
and that life was ultimately an accident of time and chance. Theism 
predicted this universe was purposely created by God with man in mind. 
Scientists find the universe is exquisitely fine-tuned for carbon-based 
life to exist in this universe. Moreover it is found, when scrutinizing the 
details of chemistry, that not only is the universe fine-tuned for carbon 
based life, but is specifically fine-tuned for life like human life (M. 
Denton).-

6. Naturalism/Materialism predicted complex life in this universe should be 
fairly common. Theism predicted the earth is extremely unique in this 
universe. Statistical analysis of the hundreds of required parameters which 
enable complex organic life to be possible on earth gives strong indication 
the earth is extremely unique in this universe (Gonzalez). -

7. Naturalism/Materialism predicted it took a very long time for life to 
develop on earth. Theism predicted life to appear abruptly on earth after 
water appeared on earth (Genesis 1:10-11). Geo-chemical evidence from the 
oldest sedimentary rocks ever found on earth indicates that complex 
photo-synthetic life has existed on earth as long as water has been on the 
face of earth. -

8. Naturalism/Materialism predicted the first life to be relatively simple. 
Theism predicted that God is the source for all life on earth. The simplest 
life ever found on Earth is far more complex than any machine man has made 
through concerted effort. (Michael Denton PhD) -

9. Naturalism/Materialism predicted the gradual unfolding of life would 
(someday) be self-evident in the fossil record. Theism predicted complex 
and diverse animal life to appear abruptly in the seas in God’s fifth day 
of creation. The Cambrian Explosion shows a sudden appearance of many 
different and completely unique fossils within a very short “geologic 
resolution time” in the Cambrian seas. -

10. Naturalism/Materialism predicted there should be numerous transitional 
fossils found in the fossil record, Theism predicted sudden appearance and 
rapid diversity within different kinds found in the fossil record. Fossils 
are consistently characterized by sudden appearance of a group/kind in the 
fossil record(disparity), then rapid diversity within that group/kind, and 
then long term stability and even deterioration of variety within the 
overall group/kind, and within the specific species of the kind, over long 
periods of time. Of the few dozen or so fossils claimed as transitional, 
not one is uncontested as a true example of transition between major animal 
forms out of millions of collected fossils. -

11. Naturalism/Materialism predicted animal speciation should happen on a 
somewhat constant basis on earth. Theism predicted man was the last species 
created on earth – Man (our genus ‘modern homo’ as distinct from the highly 
controversial ‘early homo’) is the last generally accepted major fossil 
form to have suddenly appeared in the fossil record. (Tattersall; Luskin)–

12. Naturalism/Materialism predicted much of the DNA code was junk. Theism 
predicted we are fearfully and wonderfully made – ENCODE research into the 
DNA has revealed a “biological jungle deeper, denser, and more difficult to 
penetrate than anyone imagined.”. -

13. Naturalism/Materialism predicted a extremely beneficial and flexible 
mutation rate for DNA which was ultimately responsible for all the 
diversity and complexity of life we see on earth. Theism predicted only God 
created life on earth – The mutation rate to DNA is overwhelmingly 
detrimental. Detrimental to such a point that it is seriously questioned 
whether there are any truly beneficial, information building, mutations 
whatsoever. (M. Behe; JC Sanford) -

14. Naturalism/Materialism predicted morality is subjective and illusory. 
Theism predicted morality is objective and real. Morality is found to be 
deeply embedded in the genetic responses of humans. As well, morality is 
found to be deeply embedded in the structure of the universe. Embedded to 
the point of eliciting physiological responses in humans before humans 
become aware of the morally troubling situation and even prior to the event 
even happening.

15. Naturalism/Materialism predicted that we are merely our material bodies 
with no transcendent component to our being, and that we die when our 
material bodies die. Theism predicted that we have minds/souls that are 
transcendent of our bodies that live past the death of our material bodies. 
Transcendent, and ‘conserved’, (cannot be created or destroyed),

comments.text:
+Comical Jester Fundamental error in your explanation is that protein isn't 
synthesized based on DNA sequence; it's based on RNA sequence. In 
extension, T is not used in amino acid synthesis, its RNA equivalent is U.
comments.author: cheekity bob

comments.text:
like Alessandro said amino acids are the building blocks for proteins they 
are made from codons which originally come from RNA which come from DNA. 
The amino acids create a polypeptide chain which create a protein.
comments.author: Perustyle011

comments.text:
Basically the body codes for amino acids using base triplets (a combination 
of the bases used in DNA (These bases are referred to as Bases A, T, C and 
G. Base A will always go with Base T and base C will always go with base G, 
this is called complimentary base pairing). For example it might use A, C 
and T, this specific code will create an amino acid (please note this is 
called protein synthesis and occurs at the ribosome, which is part of the 
cell) a certain combination of amino acids well then code to create a 
protein. Now you see if the DNA mutates then this means the base triplet 
might be different perhaps it's now A, A and C thus making a different 
amino acid and therefore effecting what protein is made or the 
functionality of a protein.
comments.author: Comical Jester

comments.text:
to add to Alessandro Mirto comment: different proteins in the body are made 
up of different arrangements of amino acids :)

usually occurs when there is damage to the genes that tell the cell when to

comments.author: Chris Hammang

comments.text:
+Pugster That doesn't answer his question at all, you just explained how 
cancer starts, which isn't what he was asking.
comments.author: Anthony Khodanian

comments.text:
This is because cancer changes the genetic code to a point were it can 
multiply rapidly and still somehow not destroy itself to an extent..... the 
telomeres at the end of the cells (they protect the chromosomes, 
essentially they slow down aging and deterioration in them causes aging, 
look them up) replenish themselves and the cell goes through rapid 
division. These rapidly diving cells cause more harm than good in the body 
and yes some do go through mutation and die but many survive. Picture a 
normal cell dividing but you know some mutations happen during division and 
a replica or both cells may die but most of the time it can replicate fine. 
The same is with cancer it may be different from your normal cells but the 
same rules apply, it just divides a lot. Not only that but those new cancer 
cells suck up nutrients and food for the rest of your body, hence why 
cancer kills.
comments.author: Pugster

comments.text:
When a mistake happens, it happens to only one cell at a time. One single 
cell has a mutation that makes it multiply uncontrollably. Soon there are 
millions of uncontrollable cells, any mistakes which prevent growth will 
only affect a small percentage of those.
comments.author: Anthony Khodanian

comments.text: +Nik Robinson Like hot butter through a knife.
comments.author: patrickguyum

comments.text:
well think of it on a smaller scale, a knife for example. Say you move a 
knife at 2mph towards a stick of butter. Once the knife hits the butter, it 
will move through it at 2mph. So say the stick of butter was moving towards 
the knife at 3mph and the knife is still moving at 2mph, the knife is still 
going to cut through the butter. But this time its going to cut through the 
butter at 5mph. So a 9mm bullet is moving at 820 miles per hour at a person 
who is moving at 830 miles per hour toward the bullet. The end result would 
be the same as the same bullet being fired at 1,650mph a still person . 
Woah :)
comments.author: Nik Robinson

comments.text:
You're not applying both variables of a vector, you are missing the 
direction part.

If you are travelling in the direction of the bullet, it would never hit 
you because you move faster.
If you are travelling towards the bullet, you would likely explode 
depending on the round.

comments.text:
The capacity for aggression comes from resource scarcity, most likely. Most 
primates are aggressive, sans the Bonobo, which devolved in a more fertile 
region in Africa. Humans will kill out of fear, or in self-defense. (If I 
though my life was in immediate peril, then I'd do whatever it takes to 
continue breathing)

Humans are tool users, so we can make up for out lack of claws with clubs, 
axes, knives, swords, bows and guns. When one tool becomes unavailable, or 
out of date, we create new tools, often better then the tools that came 
before. Killing another human being isn't per-se 'natural', in that it's 
easy to do, for most. However, nearly every human being with a functional 
fight or flight response is capable of violence under the right 
circumstances.

I have a question for the internet: is there ever an age in which we should 
simply accept death? Since cancers are typically (though not always) 
diseases of senescence, and death is currently inevitable, at what point 
should we humans accept our end and stop prolonging our lives? Is there 
even a point in which we should, or should we endlessly struggle to live 
forever?﻿

I am on the internet because unfortunately in this world there is nothing

Secondly, Nature is good, nature is what created us in the first place, 
earth, the solar system, everything we know about and everything we have no 
idea about, was created by nature. And by you suggesting nature isn't good 
enough and we can improve nature, are you really so arrogant that you 
believe humans could have created a better universe than what we already 
have? You say we are 'striving for improvement' well in my opinion, humans 
may be attempting that but really look at our race, all we seem to have 
done is turn lovely countries full of trees, grasslands, thousands of 
species of animals all co-existing into masses of concrete and buildings ( 
and the oceans we shouldn't even be able to be on since we are land 
mammals, into a massive pool of our unwanted rubbish. it is disgusting) 
with only humans and a few select animals we decide we like enough to have 
as pets, who pose no threat, and any dogs or other animals that are 
considered dangerous are killed. You suggest my opinions are similar to 
genocide. I am not suggesting killing of every human, that is despicable 
and the fact any person has ever attempted that is one of the reasons i 
despise humans. We as a whole have made too many animals extinct, too many 
plants extinct. We believe humans are superior to every other animal, why 
because we have morals? is knowingly harming, torturing, killing masses of 
animals incapable of protecting themselves just to benefit the human race a 
good thing? I am not saying i am right, who knows you may be right, if

+Rugby Mad Aunty "Just let nature happen"... Why are you on the internet, 
then? You know that's not natural.

Seriously people, what is it with this worship of nature as though it was 
perfect and we're just ruining it? Nature is good, yes, but if we can 
improve on that, then why the heck not? What is wrong with being ambitious? 
What is wrong with striving for improvement? Had we not always wanted to 
live longer and tried our best to stay alive, you probably wouldn't have 
been born, or your best friend wouldn't have, or your lover, or 
any/everyone you care about...

And please stop with all the "overpopulation" crap. Anyone arguing for that 
is either a hypocrite or terribly selfish, because, if you really think 
more deaths is a good thing, why don't you just kill yourself? Or would you 
rather have your mother die, or again, your brother, best friend, 
boy/girlfriend, or anyone you care about? You do realize anyone we're 
letting die has family and people who care about them, right? Why is death 
so cheap as long as you're not involved?

Please think for a moment before proposing what is, to me, equivalent to 
genocide.

comments.text:
A. Your link is broken, but a quick Google search found what you were 
linking to anyway.

B. The statistic that you cited, presumably from the page you linked, is 
somewhat misleading. Your cited source states that about 1% are born with a 
CHD, about 0.1% are born with a Critical CHD (The immediatly life 
threatening kind), and cites no statistics in terms of survival rates. If 
you would post such statistics I would be grateful.

C. Staticics from 
http://www.cancer.org/cancer/cancerbasics/lifetime-probability-of-developing-or-dying-from-cancer
would indicate that around 43% of people will be affected by cancer at some 
point in their lives, which makes it 43 times more likely to affect someone 
than a congenital heart defect, which is probably why it gets more money 
and attention.

I in no way disagree that we should fund research into CHD, and anything 
that causes people to die, really. However, I think you are, for whatever 
reason, either overestimating the effect of CHDs or underestimating the 
effect of cancer.
comments.author: Ben

comments.text:
+kolpy99 
It's true. There are more cases of heart defects than of cancer at 
childhood for simple environmental reasons. There are far fewer cases of 
adults requiring treatment for CHD, but that's for a simple reason as well. 
Most of them are dead. As for being a niche market, know that nearly1 in 
every 100 births results in some type of heart defect:

http://www.marchofdimescom/baby/congenital-heart-defects.aspx

Remember that story of the otherwise healthy football player who collapsed 
and died on the field? That was due to an undiagnosed hole in their septum 
my friend.

I'm not saying cancer doesn't deserve funding, but understand that 
treatments exist. Depending on the severity of the CHD, there are many 
times no solutions, only patches. The child in question may live to 6 
before their heart fails. They may make it to their teens and succumb to 
pulmonary hypertension. One might think a transplant is the answer, but the 
dismal statistics say otherwise. I made an obvious comment, and yet most 
people have no idea.

kind of mind-numbing effect I have while dreaming too, and I had woken up 
to that. Once my logic realized it was a dream and I was not hurt the pain 
slowly number and my leg was fine within a minute or two. 

It's just my take on it without any extensive research or facts, so take 
what you like from it. I'd be cool to see an episode on the effect tho, 
rather than my sloppy put together theory.

C-123 Providers used to spray this stuff around our base camp. It would get

comments.text:
Hello doowoplover - the doctors often say that because all the members of a 
family have a disease then it must be 'genetic', but it may simply be that 
they are exposed to the same toxins, or because they live in the same house 
are susceptible to the fungi there, or are eating the same pesticide 
covered food, or have all had the same vaccinations, or live by a main road 
in which nanoparticles and lead have been spewing out all the time from 
exhausts, or have all had the same dental fillings from a poor dentist, or 
via the electrical equipment in their house or the position of their house 
are exposed to the same background radiation.  And if they all live by a 
wind farm this too can have its effects. Cancer and diabetes can rear up 
much later than the pathogen that caused it, so often you can have lived 
away from home for several years before it appears.   So I think the 
genetic argument is often quite weak.  Incidentally I am pleased you beat 
cancer, it shows it can be done
comments.author: AAH Replies

comments.text:
All kinds of bacteria and viruses "invade" our bodies on a regular basis. 
Our bodies produce anti bodies that attack these "invaders". If someone has 
a very strong immune system, as I do, then they will not be as susceptible 
as others. However, I did have early stage prostate cancer. But I breezed 
through the treatment, and I've been in remission for nearly 8 years.

Some people are predisposed to diseases because of genetics. My father and 
mother, and two of my sisters, as well as myself have type 2 diabetes 
(adult onset diabetes). This has to be inherited. But this is not 
considered fatal, and can be treated with medication.

People who live near a toxic site have more cases of cancer, than people 
from other areas. There are many different scenarios for someone developing 
cancer.

Tumor cells can bud off early in the cancer process. When the malignancy is

need to find a way to make our body get better at seeking out and 
destroying abnormal cells in our bodies early on, but since the efficiency 
of our bodies decreases and we become weaker and more susceptible to 
diseases, it makes it harder to recover from them. If we had some way to 
keep our cells dividing/replenishing so we're at the health level of a 20 
year old, we could fight off almost all diseases that the elderly can't.

and it's usually the fact that we can't recover that keeps us from 
surviving that cause.﻿

comments.author: Joseph Maglaris

comments.text:
+SchoolKidInTheDMV That is not how it works. Cancer is a mutation in cells 
that causes rapid and uncontrolled cell mitosis - you can't cure it, just 
like you can't *cure* viruses, it's too complex and too diverse to actually 
prevent it with anything short of gene therapy. If we actually modified a 
person's genes in an attempt to stop cancer mutations from forming, we'd be 
more likely to get them cancer. If we could do gene therapy like that, the 
entire world would be more vulnerable to viruses, because it would cripple 
the genetic diverstity that cancer is caused by - a genetic diversity that 
is, most of the time, actually pretty usefull. The only cures are 
treatments, and those treatments take time, and are hazardous - 
chemotherapy is a series of drugs that target the essential systems that 
keep cancer cells alive - if they rapidly reproduce, the drug targets it. 
The problem is this can also cripple things in your body that aren't 
cancer, like hair follicles, which reproduce quickly so that you can have a 
lot of hair. This is why cancer patients are often bald.

The only thing we can do is keep researching for better chemicals and 
better treatements, and keep cancer causing agents out of out lives.
comments.author: Mirror Image

not yet understand the minute workings of cells.  It is apparently very 
complex that researchers can hope to unveil a tiny layer of the puzzle at a 
time. Like he said in the video, there are billions of cells in our body 
and each one of which could turn bad into cancer at anytime.  Thanks to our 
immune system that we do not have cancer more than it is now.
Preventing the start of a new cancer appears to be to avoid those noxious 
insults to the cells ( smoke, UV light, alcohol etc.) and to have our 
immune system at a high level of alertness.
For now, all we can do is try to treat those cancers that have already gain 
foothold and grown to visible size.

top_comment.text:
I'm not really a smart person, so if you can try to explain this as easily 
as possible. It can be short or long.
Are cells and atoms different things? Or are one of them made of the other 
one? Are they the same thing? If not, which one is the brain made out of? 
Could we live without a brain?﻿
top_comment.author: Klaty

comments.text:
EXTREMELY different.  Atoms not only make up cells, but they make up all 
matter, from a pebble to our sun.  Atoms exist in the form of every element 
found on the periodic table, and millions of them can be found in a single 
cell.  Of course, millions of cells can then be found in a single organ, 
such as the brain.  Brain cells (neurons) are different from cells found in 
other parts of the body such as on your skin, because they are composed of 
a different combo of atoms in a different order.  So technically, both 
cells and atoms make up your brain.  To answer that last question, we 
couldn't live w/o a brain, but we actually can live with only half of one, 
although we wouldn't function as well, obviously.  Sorry, I don't know too 
much about that, specifically, but I'm sure any further questions could be 
taken care of by a few minutes on wikipedia.
comments.author: Seamus Balinth

comments.text:
Allow me to explain better:
Atoms are composed of electrons (little negative charged balls) and a 
nucleus(with positive and neutral charged balls). Some atoms are unstable, 
they need to share electrons with others to be stable. When they do such, 
they are molecules(or ionic compounds/ metals, but, for the sake of 
simplicity, the info in parenthesys is unneeded). Molecules can have an 
unstable atom at their edge, that will let molecules combine with 
eachother. Lots of molecules make up macromolecular stuff. If said stuff is 
not water or a salt(ionic compound), then it is biologic. Biologic matter, 
if combined in a specific way, may create cells. Bigger cells may get 
smaller cells to help them (mythocondriae are used by animal cells to 
process oxygen and sugar/fat), and then they can then be called 
eucarionthys cells. These are the ones that make up animals, plants and 
fungi. The brain is made out of those. These cells make tissues, 
collections of cells with same behaviour: bone tissue, blood tissue, 
nervous tissue, muscle, etc. 

The brain is composed of nervous tissue. Nervous tissue stimulates other 
tissues to do their job, through electrical impulses released due to atomic 
flow inside of nervous cells. Therefore, without a brain, other human 
tissue wouldn't be able to do their job and deteriorate (that is, their 
cells will stop absorbing energy and the smaller cells inside them will 
consume their hosts. While blood tissue dies quickly, bone tissue takes a 
long time). Life, however, is a term with different interpretations. I'll 
use this one "You're alive as long as you're not dead.". So, each cell has 
a different life. The death of all the cells in a tissue makes the tissue 
dead. The death of all the tissues make the organ dead. With all the organs 
dead, you are dead. Final veredict: you can live without a brain, but for a 
short time. When your brain dies, the medula still makes your heart beat 
for some time, then dies right after (so in 10 minutes you'd be considered 
dead, unless you can keep the medula alive. What would define your life 
time then would be the blood tissue, when it dies everything is done.). 
When your heart dies first, tho, hte brain stays alive for 6-72 hours.

So, in short, atoms - molecules - macromolecules - compounds - biological 
compounds - small cells - big cells - tissues - organs - organism (which 
refers to you). In crescent order. Hope I helped.

the other microbes that exist in our body will "live" like nothing 
happened. This will go on for seconds, minutes or even days depending on 
the type of cell or microbe.
Also, organs donated after death (if preserved properly) have a "shelf 
life" (according to eHow) of: hearts and lungs need to be installed within 
five hours, livers within 18 hours, pancreas within 20 hours, kidneys 
within three days, corneas within 10 days and within five years or more for 
heart valves, skin and bones.

top_comment.text:
Actually, there is a theoretical cure for cancer. It's only theoretical 
because it's untested. But the theoretical cure is from nightshade plants. 
Enzymes in nightshade plants are designed to break down cell walls and 
cause them to collapse. This can potentially be used to eliminate cancer 
without all of those invasive surgeries. However, those enzymes don't just 
target cancer cells. They can also damage healthy cells as well.

So perhaps there's not a cure for cancer yet. But there is a theoretical 
cure. So my question is...why is nobody looking into this?!﻿

comments.text:
Everything can. Cancer is one of those things where there's no one cause. 
It's a combination of factors in your body and lifestyle that can decrease 
or increase your likelihood of getting cancer. And there's nothing you can 
do about it. Sure you can make sure you have a really healthy diet which 
will decrease the chances of getting some cancers, but your susceptibility 
to other cancers could increase.

Because of this there's no point looking for a vaccine for cancer. We're 
better of making treatments more effective, making it easier to spot 
cancer, and educating people on the symptoms of cancer so we don't ever 
leave it to late
