comments.text:
The boat does actually sink into the water till the volume of water the 
boat is pressing into matches the volume of air inside the boat.Think of a 
beach ball, if it was thrown into water it floats cuz of the air being less 
dense...Boats like the titanic lets say, are made of steel so they require 
a bigger base (which is full of air). A metal canue wouldnt float though 
due to the dense metal and lack of air, which is why boats tend to have a 
mast that is hollow
comments.author: Chazz vc

comments.text:
Sigh, I'll answer your question even though it's rather simple. Since a 
boat is hollow, it's interior is filled with air (not actually hollow.) 
Since air is WAY less dense than water the entire boat ends up being less 
dense than water and it becomes buoyant in water. Sort of like a hot air 
balloon with hot, less dense air floating on cool more dense air.

comments.text:
It is silly to think that the amount of money spent on cancer research 
should directly relate the cancer death rate. Cancer is a very complicated 
thing. The money goes in to all sorts of studies, but that doesn't mean 
they are going to find a solution to stage 3 or stage 4 cancer. Many people 
don't even know they have cancer until its too late. If everyone found out 
they had cancer in the early stages, I bet the death rate would be much 
much lower.

But people ignore symptoms. Part of that is because if you have an issue 
and you look online, just about everything is a symptom of cancer.  You 
aren't going to go to the doctors unless you discover a lump or are so 
debilitated that you have no other choice. Otherwise people would be at the 
doctors office all the time.

Im sure a lot of the money that goes in to cancer research just ends up in 
someone's pocket, but that isn't the main reason we haven't had that much 
success saving people. Its because cancer is your own body attacking 
itself. How do you fight that? The only ways we currently know include 
either literally destroying our bodies with radiation and chemo, and 
cutting out large chunks to remove the cancer. The treatments are almost as 
bad as the disease. There isn't a way to tell a specific part of the body 
to stop replicating cells.

comments.text:
+RustingPeacefully That's pretty rude to suggest. Also of course saying 
live in the UK is correct. It's just not a country, it's a sovereign state. 
It's pretty offensive to many people from the UK to suggest it's all one 
country.

Also if you had a history of hundreds of years of on and off conflict with 
another country obviously there will be cultural divides. It doesn't mean 
that if you are from one part of the Scotland you hate someone from 
England. It just means there are significant differences.

Also the only time I have a problem is when someone suggests that the UK is 
one country. I don't have a problem with saying I live in the UK, because 
of course it's correct. My nationality and my national pride comes from 
being Scottish. Just as someone from England's national pride comes from 
being English etc.

Part of the reason this is a sensitive topic is because there was a history 
of oppression between our countries. It of course no longer exists but the 
remnants linger yet.
comments.author: HaloMortal

comments.text:
Judging by these comments the UK seems like a bunch of whiny siblings who 
are all mad at each other and yelling "YOU'RE NOT MY BROTHER/SISTER."

Also, if he lives in England its still very, very correct to say that he 
lives in the UK because England is in the UK thus whoever lives in England 
also lives in the UK. It's incredibly stupid to suggest otherwise.
comments.author: RustingPeacefully

comments.text:
+Daniel Price I'm sorry but it is arguable, because as I just said. The 
term country is incorrect when describing the UK. The UK is a sovereign 
state and has constituent countries. You cannot have a country with 
countries within it. You can however have a sovereign state with countries 
inside of it.

Also as I just said I know the term British can refer to both but there is 
a predominate English influence over the term British. I prefer to be known 
as Scottish rather than British because it defines my culture much more 
than the term british. I'm not opposed to being called British, I just 
refer to myself as Scottish not British because I find the term commonly 
confused with only England.
comments.author: HaloMortal

comments.text:
+Ben Kolbeck I study history as well as computer science in Dundee, and I 
was born and raised on Scotland. There is a unifying nature of being 
British of course, but that doesn't make it the same country. There isn't a 
overarching nationality, there has been an overarching monarchy and the two 
are not the same.

If you argue that a unified monarchy constitutes as a country in it's own 
right you would be incorrect. The union of kingdoms did not represent the 
unification of peoples. It was power over multiple countries. It would be 
like saying the Angevin Empire was all one country. It of course stretched 
from England and across the west of France, however it wasn't one country. 
The peoples within the empire were separate but unified under the crown or 
the influence of the crown.

Now if you want to argue that it is a country you are incorrect. The term 
used to describe the UK is a sovereign state which you should know if you 
study history. It is made up of constituent countries. So indeed the 
statement that the UK is a country is incorrect. The statement would be 
correct if you said it was a sovereign state.

I am also proud to be known as british. However it should be recognised 
that England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland are not the same. I 
identify as Scottish because I am, you identify as English because you are. 
We both may identify as British.

I however prefer to be known as my national identity and country which is 
Scotland because I feel it is in many ways separate. Just as you would 
prefer to be known as English because is many ways it is separate.

The historical and cultural difference for being Scottish, English, Welsh 
or Northern Irish is strong enough to warrant them as separate national 
identities.

I however am not against identifying as British (although there may be an 
incorrect stigma attached to it). Also a lot of the national identity of 
being Scottish, Welsh or Northern Irish is wiped out by the term British 
when used abroad (mostly the United States) because the attachment of 
certain very English centric ideas to the word. I am perfectly okay to 
identify as British to non ignorant people, but you never know whom might 
be.

Also being Scottish there is a certain feeling of separation from England. 
Not a spiteful one but the mentality of a Scottish person I find is very 
different from an English person.
comments.author: HaloMortal

comments.text:
+HaloMortal No, you don't know what you're talking about. The UK is a 
single country - that is a fact. It is a sovereign nation state. Even if 
you think they are not the same nation, there is a unifying state and 
therefore it is a country. 

I would argue that there is a unifying culture. Yes, Scotland, England, 
Wales, and Northern Ireland have their own cultures and they are all 
nations in their own right. But that doesn't mean that there isn't also an 
overarching nationality; there is a sense of Britishness that is distinct 
from a sense of Englishness, Scottishness, Welshness or Northern Irishness. 
In the same way that I live in Manchester and so identify as a Mancunian, I 
am English and also identify as a Brit. I am more proud to be part of the 
UK than I am part of England; it is a greater nation in my view. 

I also know the history, I live in the UK, I see myself as from the UK, and 
I study history at university in the UK.
comments.author: Ben Kolbeck

comments.text:
+Ben Kolbeck I live in Scotland and I'm Scottish. The UK is not a single 
country. It is a collection of countries. I know what I'm talking about. 
The union of kingdoms was not the union of national identity. If you have 
read about all the wars that took place you would know this is the case.

Scotland has it's own language, Wales has it's own language and England has 
it's own language. Scotland has it's own culture, Wales has it's own 
culture and England has it's own culture and these are not the same.

There are different histories. It is not one national identity but a 
descriptor for a collection of nations. There is in fact a Scottish 
government as well. It's pretty insulting to people in England, Scotland 
and Wales to refer to the UK as one country because it is not.

If you read any history about the UK you would know this. I do actually 
know what I'm talking about because I live here and know the history.
comments.author: HaloMortal

comments.text:
+HaloMortal The UK is a country. It has a national identity and a 
government. It's a nation state.
comments.author: Ben Kolbeck

comments.text:
+Daniel Price Well no the UK isn't a country. It is a collection of 
countries. It would be like saying. Scotland is a country, England is a 
country and Wales is a country with different histories and cultures. The 
UK is in reference to the union of the kingdoms of these countries.

Saying the UK is a country makes about as much sense as saying that South 
America is a country.

captions.text: Hey, Vsauce. Michael here.
Since this video began
more than a million of your cells have
died. It's natural, don't worry.
But you are literally covered with death
Dead stuff. Fingernails, your hair,

the outermost layer of your skin - all
made out of dead things.

And you are losing this dead stuff
constantly. Every week
about 5.5 grams of dead skin sheds off of your body.
Ohio State University found that 80%

of that material you see indoors,
beautifully dancing across sunbeams,
is dead human skin.
But for the most part, you are made out of
living stuff. You are a biological
furnace, burning food energy to move and breathe and

think and stay warm. As you can see on
Grand-Illusions[.com], the heat from your own
hand while you sit still
is enough to run a Stirling engine.
Your cells are busy and active and dividing

millions and millions of times every day.
In fact, because of that, you shouldn't even
really be called a person.
You should be called a persON

and on and on and on and on and on and
on and on... But here's the really
mind-blowing
thing about the mind sustaining process of cell division,

the replication of instructions.
DNA for each daughter cell
requires copying an exact sequence
of three billion nucleotides. That's a lot.

Luckily, our bodies are perfect-ly happy
to do it but they're not perfect.

Every time a single cell in your body
divides, the enzymes that synthesize
your DNA
make 120,000 mistakes.
Some of these mistakes

wind up being beneficial. Some of these
mistakes wind up being harmful and
some are just neutral,

they don't make a difference.
But if a mistake,

a mutation in a cell's DNA, causes the
cell to behave abnormally
and stimulate its own growth, ignore signals to stop,

stimulate the body to give it its own
blood supply, potentially

multiply forever and unstick from
where it began to spread throughout the body,
it becomes a special type of cell.

We have found 200 diseases with various
origins and natures that

fit this description. Despite being
different, they often go by the same name:
cancer.
DNA mutations occur randomly in your body

but they can also be inherited or caused
by the environment.

For example, exposure to ultraviolet
radiation from the Sun

can cause all kinds of damage,
including genetic damage.

If little or no skin protection is
used, the accumulation of all these types of damage
can be quite dramatic. This man drove a truck
for years, exposing one side of his face to more sunlight
than the other.
And for 15 years this woman worked in a room
that had the same window. A window to her left.
Environmental damage to the body,
whether cancer-causing or not, is serious business.

In fact, giraffes have black tongues
because the dark pigmentation protects
their tongues
from solar radiation while they're hanging out all day.

Go back far enough, beyond where sunshine
hits, and their tongues are pink.

Given the sheer number of environmental
dangers to our DNA

and the sheer number of mistakes our own
bodies make with our DNA every day,

it is incredible that we all aren't
developing cancers constantly

and immediately after being born.
One of the things we have to thank
is our body's own version of autocorrect.

Biological mechanisms, like proofreading
and mismatch repair,
catch and correct or stop more than 99% of errors.
We grow old and pass away for many,

many reasons.
But when it comes to cancers, our bodies'
own internal autocorrect is like the autocorrect

on your phone. It's pretty good, but it's
not perfect. Cancers

still develop, especially after the
accumulation of mistakes and mutations

over time. I'm incredibly grateful to
Cancer Research UK.

They helped me a lot with this
episode, and thanks to work by groups like them,

we are at an accelerating rate finding
ways to prevent and control cancer

beyond what our bodies can do alone.
I mean, after all, natural selection can
only see so much
because of the selection shadow.

We aren't all the same and if your genetic
variations make you and your children
more successful at reproducing,

well, what do you know, your
characteristics become more common.
But this phenomenon has a weak influence

here. Later in life, after your role in
reproduction and raising offspring to
independence
has passed.
We have found evidence of the selection shadow
at work with mice and bats.

Raised under perfect conditions, with
veterinary medicine and safe lives,
mice only live about two to three years.

Whereas bats, with similar sizes and
metabolisms, can live for

thirty years or more. The significant
difference here is that

unlike mice, bats have had in the wild
for millions of years
fewer predators - a smaller chance of dying early

due to extrinsic mortality. They've, on
average, had more days for natural selection

to influence. This could be a very good
explanation for why diseases that affect
our complex multicellular selves
late in life are still with us.
But wait, why are humans living so long today?
I mean, in the past, but genetically recently, weren't
teenagers considered middle aged?

Not really. Well, it's true that in the
past life expectancies were quite
a bit lower, a life expectancy is merely an

average number of years a person was
expected to live as soon as they were born.
And in the past, infant mortality was so high

the average was brought down
significantly. It's true that in the
early 1600s, here
in England, life expectancy was only 35 years.
But if you made the age of 21... Well,
you could easily expect to live well into your 60s.
Lifespans that go beyond the age of reproduction have

always made sense for humans,
because we are intelligent
and social, useful to one another and our children
take a lot of time and guidance to gain independence.

But that just moves the selection shadow ahead. 
It's still there,
suggesting that, in the end, our bodies might just be
tools our sex cells use to reproduce

and grow up to do it again. Nature and
time haven't helped our bodies battle
late acting diseases because a chicken
is just an egg's way of making another egg.

But maybe not for long. Our minds and
modern science technology engineering
and mathematics are making progress

against late acting diseases.
And when it comes to cancers,
Cancer Research UK points out that 40 years ago
only one in four people lived ten years or longer

after being diagnosed.
Today that number is 2 in 4.

And they believe that in only twenty years
that statistic could be as high as 3 in 4.

Refrigeration and sanitation are
tackling stomach cancers caused by infection,

vaccines are preventing cervical cancer,
anti-smoking campaigns and reductions
of obesity and diabetes and the elimination

of cancer-causing chemicals from our
everyday lives are giving us an edge.
We learn more every single day. The process
is slow, but steady. Because cancer is not just

one thing. It's unlikely there will ever
be a single cure for cancer because
there are two hundred different types

of cancers. But there will be cures and
better methods of prevention

and detection.
Advances are coming from all over.

For example, what we have learned about
controlling proton beams because of the
Large Hadron Collider

has reduced the need for special shields
during the removal of eye tumours.

The statistical surprise that cancers
aren't more common in our bodies
is a sign that we're involved in a relay race.

Natural selection already did some of the
work, now it's our turn.

When we talk about cancer
we often use the language of war:

it's a battle, it's a fight.
But the challenge

isn't so much a war with winners and
losers and surrender

as it is a mutiny.
We can't help the fact that we are all at sea.
Natural selection at least gave us boats
but now we are making where those boats go
our decision.
And as always,
thanks for watching.

title: Why Don't We All Have Cancer?
